definition: A cytotoxic T-cell lymphoma, usually of alpha/beta lineage, preferentially involving the subcutaneous tissue in a lobular pattern.
clinical: Presents with indurated erythematous plaques or nodules, typically without ulceration. Clinically mimics panniculitis or medium-to-large vessel vasculitis.
pathogenesis: Derived from cytotoxic T-cells targeting the subcutaneous fat.
macroscopic: Deep indurated plaques/nodules; usually lacks surface changes (no scale or ulceration initially).
microscopic: The infiltrate is concentrated in the subcutaneous lobules (lobular panniculitis pattern). The epidermis and dermis are typically spared. The infiltrate consists of lymphocytes of varying sizes (small to large) rimming adipocytes (rimming of fat vacuoles). Necrosis and nuclear dust (karyorrhexis) are often present. Occasional mitotic figures.
ancillary_studies: IHC: CD3+, CD8+, Beta F1+ (Alpha/Beta phenotype), TIA-1+ (cytotoxic), Granzyme B+, CD4- (usually), CD56 negative, EBER (EBV) negative. Ki-67 shows a high proliferation rate in lymphocytes rimming adipocytes.
differential_diagnosis: Lupus Panniculitis (Lupus Profundus) - distinguished by low Ki-67 rate in rimming cells, presence of lymphoid follicles, plasma cells, and CD123+ clusters (though lecture notes Ki-67 is the most reliable discriminator). Gamma-Delta T-Cell Lymphoma (TCR-delta+). Extranodal NK/T-cell lymphoma.
prognosis_and_prediction: Generally indolent compared to Gamma-Delta TCL. 5-year survival is generally good. Hemophagocytic syndrome is a potential complication.

related_figures.legend: Low power view showing dense infiltrate in the subcutus with sparing of the overlying epidermis and dermis. (Time: 157s)
Lobular infiltration of lymphocytes within the subcutaneous fat. (Time: 216s)
Ki-67 stain showing a high proliferation rate of lymphocytes rimming individual adipocytes. (Time: 295s)

definition: An aggressive lymphoma, usually of NK-cell lineage (rarely cytotoxic T-cell), strongly associated with Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV).
clinical: Classic presentation involves destruction of central facial structures (midline granuloma). Can present as ulcerated plaques or tumors elsewhere. May be misdiagnosed as infection (e.g., Staph) due to extensive necrosis/crusting.
pathogenesis: EBV-driven proliferation of NK or cytotoxic T cells.
macroscopic: Ulcerated, necrotic lesions, often with significant tissue destruction.
microscopic: Diffuse infiltrate involving dermis and/or subcutus. Epidermotropism may be present. Angiocentricity and angiodestruction are characteristic. Infiltrate comprises small, medium, and large atypical lymphocytes with coagulative necrosis.
ancillary_studies: IHC: CD56+, Cytoplasmic CD3 epsilon+, Surface CD3- (usually), TIA-1+, Granzyme B+. EBER (EBV ISH) positive (essential for diagnosis).
differential_diagnosis: Infectious etiologies (deep fungal, atypical mycobacterial), Wegener's (GPA), Gamma-Delta T-Cell Lymphoma.

related_figures.legend: Clinical presentation showing severe destruction and ulceration of the central face. (Time: 685s)
CD56 immunostain highlighting the neoplastic cells. (Time: 952s)
EBER (EBV) in situ hybridization positivity confirming the diagnosis. (Time: 995s)

entity_name: Primary Cutaneous Aggressive Epidermotropic CD8+ T-Cell Lymphoma
definition: A rare, aggressive variant of Cutaneous T-Cell Lymphoma characterized by proliferation of CD8+ cytotoxic T-cells with marked epidermotropism.
clinical: Sudden onset of generalized plaques and nodules, often ulcerated. Notably lacks preceding patch/plaque phase (unlike Mycosis Fungoides).
pathogenesis: Neoplastic proliferation of CD8+ cytotoxic T-cells.
macroscopic: Erythematous plaques and nodules, frequently with ulceration.
microscopic: Diffuse dermal infiltrate with marked, florid epidermotropism (pagetoid spread). Necrotic keratinocytes are common. Cells show variable size and pleomorphism (small, medium, large).
ancillary_studies: IHC: CD3+, CD8+, CD4-, Beta F1+, TIA-1+, Granzyme B+. Negative for: CD56, EBER (EBV), and TCR-delta (Gamma-Delta).
differential_diagnosis: Mycosis Fungoides (CD4+ usually), Extranodal NK/T-Cell Lymphoma (CD56+, EBER+), Gamma-Delta T-Cell Lymphoma (TCR-delta+).

related_figures.diagnosis: Primary Cutaneous Aggressive Epidermotropic CD8+ T-Cell Lymphoma
related_figures.legend: Histopathology showing marked epidermotropism of lymphocytes. (Time: 1094s)

related_figures.diagnosis: Primary Cutaneous Aggressive Epidermotropic CD8+ T-Cell Lymphoma
related_figures.legend: CD8 immunostain labeling the epidermotropic lymphocytes. (Time: 1130s)

definition: A lymphoma derived from T-cells expressing the Gamma/Delta T-cell receptor, typically involving multiple tissue compartments (epidermis, dermis, subcutus).
clinical: Presents with ulcerated nodules, plaques, or deep indurated lesions. Can have scaly patches.
microscopic: Involvement of all three layers: Epidermis (necrotic keratinocytes), Dermis, and Subcutus (rimming of adipocytes). Infiltrate is usually dense and pleomorphic.
ancillary_studies: IHC: TCR-delta+ (or TCR-gamma+), Beta F1 negative. CD3+, CD2+, CD5-, CD4-, CD8+/- (often positive), CD56+/-. EBER negative. High Ki-67 proliferation rate.
differential_diagnosis: Subcutaneous Panniculitis-like T-Cell Lymphoma (Alpha/Beta phenotype, Beta F1+), Extranodal NK/T-Cell Lymphoma (EBER+), Mycosis Fungoides with Gamma-Delta phenotype.
prognosis_and_prediction: Historically considered very poor/aggressive, though recent data suggests a broader spectrum including some indolent cases.

related_figures.legend: Histopathology showing involvement of epidermis, dermis, and subcutus. (Time: 1208s)
Positive staining for TCR-delta (Delta chain) confirms the diagnosis. (Time: 1307s)

entity_name: Primary Cutaneous CD4+ Small/Medium T-Cell Lymphoproliferative Disorder
definition: An indolent provisional entity characterized by a solitary cutaneous nodule or plaque composed of small-to-medium CD4+ T-cells, often with a Follicular Helper T-cell phenotype.
clinical: Solitary papule, nodule, or plaque, typically on the face, neck, or upper trunk. If multifocal or large lesions (>5cm) are present, diagnosis of Tumor Stage Mycosis Fungoides or unspecified PTCL should be considered instead.
pathogenesis: Likely a reactive or indolent clonal proliferation of Follicular Helper T-cells.
microscopic: Dense, nodular to diffuse dermal infiltrate extending to subcutus. Minimal to no epidermotropism. Predominance of small-to-medium pleomorphic T-cells (<30% large cells). Admixed reactive cells (B-cells, histiocytes, plasma cells).
ancillary_studies: IHC: CD3+, CD4+, CD8-, CD30- (mostly). Markers of Follicular Helper T-cells: PD-1 (CD279), CXCL13, BCL6, CD10. PD-1 often highlights "rosettes" of T-cells surrounding scattered B-cells.
differential_diagnosis: Tumor Stage Mycosis Fungoides (clinical correlation required; MF usually multifocal/history of patches), Pseudolymphoma, Peripheral T-Cell Lymphoma NOS.
prognosis_and_prediction: Excellent prognosis (~100% survival). Downgraded from 'Lymphoma' to 'Lymphoproliferative Disorder' due to benign course.

related_figures.diagnosis: Primary Cutaneous CD4+ Small/Medium T-Cell LPD
related_figures.legend: Dense dermal infiltrate of small to medium lymphocytes. (Time: 1641s)

related_figures.diagnosis: Primary Cutaneous CD4+ Small/Medium T-Cell LPD
related_figures.legend: PD-1 staining showing characteristic rosetting around B-cells. (Time: 1676s)

definition: An indolent B-cell lymphoma composed of follicle center cells (centrocytes and centroblasts), typically presenting on the head or trunk.
clinical: Older adults. Solitary or grouped erythematous papules, plaques, or nodules (sometimes "Croissant" configuration) on the head, neck, or upper trunk. Excellent prognosis.
pathogenesis: Neoplastic proliferation of germinal center B-cells.
microscopic: Nodular or diffuse dermal infiltrate. Neoplastic follicles show: Reduced or absent mantle zones, no tingible body macrophages, lack of polarization (no dark/light zones), and relatively monomorphous cytology (centrocytes/centroblasts).
ancillary_studies: IHC: CD20+, CD79a+, BCL6+, CD10+ (variable/follicle restricted). BCL2 is typically negative or weak (distinct from systemic follicular lymphoma which is BCL2 strongly positive). CD21 highlights disrupted/expanded follicular dendritic cell networks. Ki-67 is low within neoplastic follicles (vs. high/polarized in reactive follicles).
differential_diagnosis: Reactive Lymphoid Hyperplasia (Pseudolymphoma) - has polarized follicles, tingible body macrophages, high Ki-67, BCL2 negative. Systemic Follicular Lymphoma - BCL2 strongly positive, t(14;18). Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma (Leg Type).

related_figures.legend: Dermal nodules of lymphocytes lacking tangible body macrophages and polarization. (Time: 2629s)
Ki-67 stain showing a low proliferation rate within the follicle, distinguishing it from a reactive germinal center. (Time: 2963s)

definition: An indolent B-cell lymphoma derived from post-germinal center marginal zone B-cells. (Note: Recently downgraded to Lymphoproliferative Disorder in some classifications due to benign course).
clinical: Red to violaceous papules, plaques, or nodules, typically on the trunk or extremities. Associated with Borrelia infection in some European cases.
pathogenesis: Clonal proliferation of marginal zone B-cells. May be antigen-driven.
microscopic: Nodular to diffuse dermal infiltrate. Composed of small lymphocytes, lymphoplasmacytoid cells, and plasma cells (often at periphery). Dutcher bodies (intranuclear inclusions) may be seen. Reactive germinal centers may be colonized.
ancillary_studies: IHC: CD20+, CD79a+, BCL2+, BCL6-, CD10-. Plasma cells show Immunoglobulin Light Chain Restriction (Kappa or Lambda monotypicity, disrupting the normal 2:1 ratio).
differential_diagnosis: Cutaneous Lymphoid Hyperplasia (Pseudolymphoma) - polytypic light chains. Follicle Center Lymphoma.

related_figures.legend: Dermal infiltrate with plasma cells present at the periphery. (Time: 3075s)
In situ hybridization showing Lambda light chain restriction (predominance). (Time: 3095s)

entity_name: Primary Cutaneous Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma, Leg Type
definition: An aggressive primary cutaneous B-cell lymphoma composed of large transformed B-cells, typically occurring on the lower legs of elderly women.
clinical: Rapidly growing, ulcerated red-blue tumors on the lower legs (though can occur elsewhere). Elderly patients (female predominance).
microscopic: Diffuse, non-epidermotropic sheets of large atypical B-cells (immunoblasts/centroblasts). High mitotic rate. Destructive growth.
ancillary_studies: IHC: CD20+, CD79a+, BCL2+ (strong), MUM1+ (IRF4), IgM+ (cytoplasmic). BCL6+/-, CD10-.
differential_diagnosis: Primary Cutaneous Follicle Center Lymphoma (diffuse variant) - usually IgM negative, MUM1 negative, BCL2 weak/negative, better prognosis.
prognosis_and_prediction: Poor prognosis compared to other cutaneous B-cell lymphomas (approx 50% 5-year survival).

related_figures.diagnosis: Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma, Leg Type
related_figures.legend: Clinical presentation of ulcerated nodules on the leg. (Time: 3166s)

related_figures.diagnosis: Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma, Leg Type
related_figures.legend: Diffuse sheets of large, atypical lymphoid cells. (Time: 3236s)

related_figures.diagnosis: Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma, Leg Type
related_figures.legend: IgM positivity, a useful marker for Leg Type lymphoma. (Time: 3251s)

definition: A rare subtype of large B-cell lymphoma where neoplastic cells reside almost exclusively within the lumen of blood vessels.
clinical: Can present with non-specific skin findings (plaques, telangiectasias) or systemic symptoms (fever of unknown origin).
pathogenesis: Loss of surface adhesion molecules preventing extravasation.
macroscopic: Indurated plaques or patches, sometimes subtle.
microscopic: Large atypical lymphoid cells confined within vascular spaces (capillaries, venules).

related_figures.legend: Blood vessels filled with atypical lymphoid cells. (Time: 3283s)
CD20 stain highlighting the intravascular B-cells. (Time: 3302s)

definition: A benign, reactive proliferation of lymphocytes in the skin that mimics lymphoma clinically and/or histologically.
clinical: Solitary or multiple papules/nodules. Can be caused by drugs, bug bites, tattoos, or idiopathic.
microscopic: Dense lymphoid infiltrate, often with germinal centers. Reactive follicles show: Polarization (dark and light zones), Tingible body macrophages, Intact mantle zones.
ancillary_studies: IHC: BCL6 confined to germinal centers, BCL2 negative in germinal centers (positive in mantle zone). Ki-67 high and polarized within germinal centers. Polytypic light chains (Kappa and Lambda present in normal ratio).
differential_diagnosis: Primary Cutaneous Follicle Center Lymphoma (Bcl2+, no tingible body macrophages, low Ki-67), Marginal Zone Lymphoma (light chain restriction).

related_figures.legend: Reactive follicle showing high mitotic rate/proliferation. (Time: 3348s)
Ki-67 stain showing high proliferation rate restricted to the germinal center. (Time: 3355s)
